newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks fall on Dow, U.S. rates fears.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks fall on Dow, U.S. rates fears.

text.p: Mexican stocks fell sharply Monday along with U.S. markets on fears of further hikes in U.S. interest rates.

"The bourse has broken support now. An important factor for us which is hitting the markets is a change in outlook for U.S. interest rates," said Jaime Fernandez, an analyst at the Interacciones brokerage in Mexico City.
The leading IPC share index ended down 94.96 points, or 2.47 percent, at 3,747.98.
"Dealers are moving ahead of expected additional hikes (in U.S. interest rates). We expect another increase in May...," Fernandez added.
Trading volume was a lifeless 48.9 million shares. Traders said this was due to caution while awaiting further developments on Wall Street.

In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 157 points on Monday following a drop of 140 points on Thursday, when Mexican financial markets were closed. U.S. financial markets were closed on Friday.
On the broad market, 112 stocks changed hands, of which decliners trounced gainers by 80 to 13.

Telecoms firm Telmex L class shares, which ended off 44 centavos (6 cents) at 15.22 pesos ($1.92), accounted for 17 percent of all shares traded and weighed most heavily on the market. Telmex ADRs meanwhile ended down 1/2 at 38-1/2 on Wall Street.
Retail chain Sears gained 60 centavos (8 cents) to 13.50 pesos ($1.71).

"Some bought Sears, but it was speculative, a few dealers are saying it will be bought by Carso," another floor trader said. Officials contacted by Reuters at both Carso and Sears declined to comment.
Holding company Grupo Carso closed down 1.50 pesos (19 cents) at 46.00 pesos ($5.81).
